sourceDesc.p: The contents of this document are generated from SOSOL.

div.p: The author of the Cypria writes that having turned himself into the likeness of a goose he [Zeus] also pursued Nemesis, and that after they had had intercourse, they produced an egg, from which was hatched Helen. When he became enamored of Leda, he became a swan, and of Europa, a bull, and of Lamia, a hoopoe, and of Danae, gold. And both in Apollonides and in Euripides it [this story] is told. Note: Eng. trans. from Dirk Obbink, Vergil's De pietate: from Ehoiae to allegory in /Vergil, Philodemus and the Augustans/ (ed. by David Armstrong, et al.; University of Texas Press, 2004), p. 185 with slight modifications by Max Lee to fit a line by line format
